PYTHON TUTORIAL¶

Welcome to this comprehensive Python tutorial for beginners! This guide is designed to help you learn the fundamentals of Python programming, even if you have no prior coding experience. We'll cover essential concepts with clear explanations, simple code examples, and exercises to help you practice. By the end of this tutorial, you'll have a solid foundation in Python and be well-prepared for Python-related interviews. Let's get started!

Python HOME¶

Welcome to the home section of our Python tutorial! Here, you'll find the starting point for your journey into the world of Python programming. We'll begin with the basics and gradually build up your knowledge.

Python Intro¶

Python is a popular, high-level, interpreted programming language known for its readability and versatility. It's used in various fields, including web development, data science, artificial intelligence, scientific computing, and automation. Its simple syntax makes it an excellent choice for beginners.

Python Get Started¶

To start coding in Python, you'll need a Python interpreter installed on your computer. You can download the latest version from the official Python website (python.org). Alternatively, you can use online platforms like Google Colab, which provide a ready-to-use Python environment in your browser.

Here's a simple "Hello, World!" program, a classic first program in many languages:

In [ ]:
print("Hello, World!")

Hello, World!

This simple line of code uses the print() function to display the text "Hello, World!" on the console.

Python Syntax¶

Python's syntax is designed to be readable and clean. One of its key features is the use of indentation to define code blocks, unlike other languages that use curly braces {} or keywords.

For example, the code inside a loop or a function is indented.

In [ ]:
if 5 > 2:
  print("Five is greater than two!")

Five is greater than two!

Important: The number of spaces for indentation is up to you, but it must be at least one, and it must be consistent within the same block of code.

Python Comments¶

Comments are lines in the code that are ignored by the interpreter. They are used to explain the code and make it more readable.

Single-line comments start with a #.

In [ ]:
# This is a single-line comment
print("Hello, World!") # This is also a comment

Hello, World!

Multi-line comments can be created using triple quotes (''' or """).

In [ ]:
"""
This is a multi-line comment.
It can span across several lines.
"""
print("Hello, World!")

Hello, World!

Python Variables¶

Variables are used to store data values. In Python, you don't need to declare the type of a variable; it is inferred when you assign a value to it.

Variable Names¶

Variable names are case-sensitive and can contain letters (a-z, A-Z), numbers (0-9), and underscores (_). They cannot start with a number.

In [ ]:
my_variable = 10
myVariable = "Hello"
_my_variable = 3.14
# 1variable = "invalid" # This would cause an error

Assign Multiple Values¶

You can assign multiple values to multiple variables in a single line.

In [ ]:
x, y, z = "Orange", "Banana", "Cherry"
print(x)
print(y)
print(z)

Orange
Banana
Cherry

You can also assign the same value to multiple variables.

In [ ]:
x = y = z = "Orange"
print(x)
print(y)
print(z)

Output Variables¶

The print() function is often used to output variable values.

In [ ]:
name = "Alice"
age = 30
print("My name is", name, "and I am", age, "years old.")

You can also use f-strings (formatted string literals) for easier formatting.

In [ ]:
name = "Bob"
age = 25
print(f"My name is {name} and I am {age} years old.")

Global Variables¶

Variables created outside of a function are global variables and can be used by anyone.

In [ ]:
x = "awesome"

def myfunc():
  print("Python is " + x)

myfunc()

If you create a variable with the same name inside a function, that variable is local and can only be used within the function. To change a global variable inside a function, use the global keyword.

In [ ]:
x = "awesome"

def myfunc():
  global x
  x = "fantastic"

myfunc()
print("Python is " + x)

Variable Exercises¶

Exercise 1: Create a variable called greeting and assign it the value "Hello, Python!". Print the value of greeting.

Exercise 2: Create three variables a, b, and c and assign them the values 1, 2, and 3 respectively in a single line. Print the values of a, b, and c.

Exercise 3: Create a global variable city with the value "New York". Create a function that prints "I live in" followed by the value of city. Call the function.

Exercise 4: Create a global variable count with the value 0. Create a function that uses the global keyword to increment the value of count by 1. Call the function twice and print the final value of count.

Python Data Types¶

In Python, variables can hold values of different types. Python is a dynamically typed language, which means you don't need to declare the type of a variable when you create it; the type is determined at runtime.

Here are the built-in data types in Python:

  • Text Type: str
  • Numeric Types: int, float, complex
  • Sequence Types: list, tuple, range
  • Mapping Type: dict
  • Set Types: set, frozenset
  • Boolean Type: bool
  • Binary Types: bytes, bytearray, memoryview
  • None Type: NoneType

You can get the data type of any object by using the type() function:

In [ ]:
x = 5
print(type(x))

y = "Hello World"
print(type(y))

z = 20.5
print(type(z))

a = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
print(type(a))

b = ("apple", "banana", "cherry")
print(type(b))

c = {"name" : "John", "age" : 36}
print(type(c))

Python Numbers¶

There are three numeric types in Python:

  • int (integers): Whole numbers, positive or negative, without decimals, of unlimited length.
  • float (floating point numbers): Numbers, positive or negative, containing one or more decimals.
  • complex: Numbers written with a "j" as the imaginary part.

You can verify the type of any number using the type() function.

In [ ]:
x = 1    # int
y = 2.8  # float
z = 1j   # complex

print(type(x))
print(type(y))
print(type(z))

Python Casting¶

Casting in Python is used to specify the data type of a variable. This is done using constructor functions:

  • int(): Constructs an integer number from an integer literal, a float literal (by removing all decimals), or a string literal (provided the string represents a whole number).
  • float(): Constructs a float number from an integer literal, a float literal, or a string literal (provided the string represents a float or an integer).
  • str(): Constructs a string from a wide variety of data types, including strings, integer literals, and float literals.
In [ ]:
x = int(1)   # x will be 1
y = int(2.8) # y will be 2
z = int("3") # z will be 3

print(x)
print(y)
print(z)

a = float(1)     # a will be 1.0
b = float(2.8)   # b will be 2.8
c = float("3")   # c will be 3.0
d = float("4.2") # d will be 4.2

print(a)
print(b)
print(c)
print(d)

e = str("s1") # e will be 's1'
f = str(2)    # f will be '2'
g = str(3.0)  # g will be '3.0'

print(e)
print(f)
print(g)

Python Strings¶

Strings in Python are sequences of characters, enclosed in either single quotes ('') or double quotes ("").

In [ ]:
print("Hello")
print('Hello')

You can assign a multiline string to a variable using three quotes:

In [ ]:
a = """Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet,
consectetur adipiscing elit,
sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt
ut labore et dolore magna aliqua."""
print(a)

Slicing Strings¶

You can return a range of characters by using the slice syntax. Specify the start index and the end index, separated by a colon.

In [ ]:
b = "Hello, World!"
print(b[2:5]) # Get the characters from position 2 to position 5 (not included)

Modify Strings¶

Python has a set of built-in methods that you can use to modify strings.

The upper() method returns the string in upper case:

In [ ]:
a = "Hello, World!"
print(a.upper())

The lower() method returns the string in lower case:

In [ ]:
a = "Hello, World!"
print(a.lower())

The strip() method removes any whitespace from the beginning or the end:

In [ ]:
a = " Hello, World! "
print(a.strip())

The replace() method replaces a string with another string:

In [ ]:
a = "Hello, World!"
print(a.replace("H", "J"))

The split() method splits the string into a list where each word is a list item:

In [ ]:
a = "Hello, World!"
print(a.split(",")) # returns ['Hello', ' World!']

Concatenate Strings¶

To concatenate, or combine, two strings you can use the + operator.

In [ ]:
a = "Hello"
b = "World"
c = a + b
print(c)

To add a space between them, add a space:

In [ ]:
a = "Hello"
b = "World"
c = a + " " + b
print(c)

Format Strings¶

As we saw in the variables section, you cannot combine strings and numbers directly. You can use f-strings or the format() method.

Using f-strings:

In [ ]:
age = 36
txt = f"My name is John, I am {age}"
print(txt)

Using the format() method:

In [ ]:
age = 36
txt = "My name is John, and I am {}"
print(txt.format(age))

You can add multiple values:

In [ ]:
quantity = 3
itemno = 567
price = 49.95
myorder = "I want {} pieces of item {} for {} dollars."
print(myorder.format(quantity, itemno, price))

You can use index numbers to ensure the arguments are placed in the correct placeholders:

In [ ]:
quantity = 3
itemno = 567
price = 49.95
myorder = "I want to pay {2} dollars for {0} pieces of item {1}."
print(myorder.format(quantity, itemno, price))

Escape Characters¶

To insert characters that are illegal in a string, use an escape character. An escape character is a backslash \ followed by the character you want to insert.

An example of an illegal character is a double quote inside a string that is surrounded by double quotes:

In [ ]:
txt = "We are the so-called \"Vikings\" from the north."
print(txt)

Other escape characters include:

  • \' Single Quote
  • \\ Backslash
  • \n New Line
  • \r Carriage Return
  • \t Tab
  • \b Backspace
  • \f Form Feed
  • \ooo Octal value
  • \xhh Hex value

String Methods¶

Python has many built-in string methods. Here are a few commonly used ones:

  • len(): Returns the length of a string.
  • count(): Returns the number of times a specified value occurs in a string.
  • find(): Searches the string for a specified value and returns the position of where it was found.
  • startswith(): Returns True if the string starts with the specified value.
  • endswith(): Returns True if the string ends with the specified value.
In [ ]:
a = "Hello, World!"
print(len(a))

txt = "I love apples, apple are my favorite fruit"
print(txt.count("apple"))

txt = "Hello, welcome to my world."
print(txt.find("welcome"))

txt = "Hello, welcome to my world."
print(txt.startswith("Hello"))

txt = "Hello, welcome to my world."
print(txt.endswith("."))

String Exercises¶

Exercise 1: Print the first character of the string "Python".

Exercise 2: Print the last character of the string "Programming".

Exercise 3: Slice the string "Hello World" to get the substring "World".

Exercise 4: Convert the string "UpperCase" to lowercase.

Exercise 5: Remove leading and trailing whitespace from the string " Stripped String ".

Exercise 6: Replace all occurrences of the letter 'a' with 'o' in the string "banana".

Exercise 7: Split the string "apple,banana,cherry" into a list of fruits.

Exercise 8: Concatenate the strings "Python" and " is fun!".

Exercise 9: Use an f-string to print "My favorite number is 7" using a variable number = 7.

Exercise 10: Use the format() method to print "I have 10 apples and 5 bananas." using variables apples = 10 and bananas = 5.

Python Booleans¶

Booleans represent one of two values: True or False. In programming, you often need to know if an expression is True or False. You can evaluate any expression in Python, and get one of two answers, True or False.

In [ ]:
print(10 > 9)
print(10 == 9)
print(10 < 9)

The bool() function allows you to evaluate any value, and give you True or False in return.

In [ ]:
print(bool("Hello"))
print(bool(15))
print(bool(""))
print(bool(0))
print(bool([]))
print(bool({}))

Python Operators¶

Operators are used to perform operations on variables and values.

Python divides the operators into the following groups:

  • Arithmetic operators: Used with numeric values to perform common mathematical operations.
  • Assignment operators: Used to assign values to variables.
  • Comparison operators: Used to compare two values.
  • Logical operators: Used to combine conditional statements.
  • Identity operators: Used to compare the objects, not if they are equal, but if they are actually the same object, with the same memory location.
  • Membership operators: Used to test if a sequence is presented in an object.
  • Bitwise operators: Used to compare (binary) numbers.

Arithmetic Operators¶

Operator Name Example
+ Addition x + y
- Subtraction x - y
* Multiplication x * y
/ Division x / y
% Modulus x % y
** Exponentiation x ** y
// Floor division x // y

Assignment Operators¶

| Operator | Example | Same as | | :------- | :-------- | :-------- | | = | x = 5 | x = 5 | | += | x += 3 | x = x + 3 | | -= | x -= 3 | x = x - 3 | | *= | x *= 3 | x = x * 3 | | /= | x /= 3 | x = x / 3 | | %= | x %= 3 | x = x % 3 | | //= | x //= 3 | x = x // 3 | | **= | x **= 3 | x = x ** 3 | | &= | x &= 3 | x = x & 3 | | |= | x |= 3 | x = x | 3 | | ^= | x ^= 3 | x = x ^ 3 | | >>= | x >>= 3 | x = x >> 3 | | <<= | x <<= 3 | x = x << 3 |

Comparison Operators¶

Operator Name Example
== Equal x == y
!= Not equal x != y
> Greater than x > y
< Less than x < y
>= Greater than or equal to x >= y
<= Less than or equal to x <= y

Logical Operators¶

Operator Description Example
and Returns True if both statements are true x < 5 and x < 10
or Returns True if one of the statements is true x < 5 or x < 4
not Reverse the result, returns False if the result is true not(x < 5 and x < 10)

Identity Operators¶

Operator Description Example
is Returns True if both variables are the same object x is y
is not Returns True if both variables are not the same object x is not y

Membership Operators¶

Operator Description Example
in Returns True if a sequence with the specified value is present in the object x in y
not in Returns True if a sequence with the specified value is not present in the object x not in y

Bitwise Operators¶

Bitwise operators are used to compare (binary) numbers:

| Operator | Name | Description | | :------- | :------ | :--------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | & | AND | Sets each bit to 1 if both bits are 1 | | | | OR | Sets each bit to 1 if one of the two bits is 1 | | ^ | XOR | Sets each bit to 1 if only one of the two bits is 1 | | ~ | NOT | Inverts all the bits | | << | Zero fill left shift | Shift left by pushing zeros in from the right and let the leftmost bits fall off | | >> | Signed right shift | Shift right by pushing copies of the leftmost bit in from the left, and let the rightmost bits fall off |

Python Lists¶

Lists are ordered, mutable collections that can store items of different data types. They are defined using square brackets [].

In [ ]:
my_list = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
print(my_list)

Access List Items¶

You can access list items by their index, starting from 0 for the first item. You can also use negative indexing to access items from the end of the list.

In [ ]:
my_list = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
print(my_list[0])
print(my_list[-1])

You can access a range of items by specifying a start and end index.

In [ ]:
my_list = ["apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange", "kiwi", "melon", "mango"]
print(my_list[2:5]) # Items from index 2 (included) to 5 (not included)
print(my_list[:4])  # Items from the beginning to index 4 (not included)
print(my_list[2:])  # Items from index 2 (included) to the end
print(my_list[-4:-1]) # Items from index -4 (included) to -1 (not included)

Change List Items¶

You can change the value of a specific item by referring to its index number.

In [ ]:
my_list = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
my_list[1] = "blackcurrant"
print(my_list)

You can also change a range of item values.

In [ ]:
my_list = ["apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange", "kiwi"]
my_list[1:3] = ["blackcurrant", "watermelon"]
print(my_list)

Add List Items¶

To add an item to the end of the list, use the append() method.

In [ ]:
my_list = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
my_list.append("orange")
print(my_list)

To add an item at a specified index, use the insert() method.

In [ ]:
my_list = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
my_list.insert(1, "mango")
print(my_list)

To append elements from another list or iterable to the current list, use the extend() method.

In [ ]:
list1 = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
list2 = ["mango", "pineapple", "papaya"]
list1.extend(list2)
print(list1)

Remove List Items¶

The remove() method removes the first occurrence of the specified value.

In [ ]:
my_list = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
my_list.remove("banana")
print(my_list)

The pop() method removes the item at the specified index. If you don't specify the index, the pop() method removes the last item.

In [ ]:
my_list = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
my_list.pop(1)
print(my_list)

my_list.pop()
print(my_list)

The del keyword removes the item at the specified index.

In [ ]:
my_list = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
del my_list[0]
print(my_list)

The del keyword can also delete the list completely.

In [ ]:
my_list = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
# del my_list # This would delete the list
# print(my_list) # This would cause an error because the list no longer exists

The clear() method empties the list.

In [ ]:
my_list = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
my_list.clear()
print(my_list)

Loop Lists¶

You can loop through the list items by using a for loop.

In [ ]:
my_list = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
for x in my_list:
  print(x)

You can also loop through the list items by referring to their index number.

In [ ]:
my_list = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
for i in range(len(my_list)):
  print(my_list[i])

You can use a while loop to loop through the list items.

In [ ]:
my_list = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
i = 0
while i < len(my_list):
  print(my_list[i])
  i = i + 1

A short hand for loop called list comprehension offers the shortest syntax for looping through lists.

In [ ]:
my_list = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
[print(x) for x in my_list]

List Comprehension¶

List comprehension provides a concise way to create lists. It consists of an expression followed by a for clause, and then zero or more if clauses.

A basic list comprehension:

In [ ]:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry", "kiwi", "mango"]
new_list = []

for x in fruits:
  if "a" in x:
    new_list.append(x)

print(new_list)

The same example with list comprehension:

In [ ]:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry", "kiwi", "mango"]
new_list = [x for x in fruits if "a" in x]
print(new_list)

Sort Lists¶

Lists have a sort() method that will sort the list alphanumerically, ascending, by default.

In [ ]:
my_list = ["orange", "mango", "kiwi", "pineapple", "banana"]
my_list.sort()
print(my_list)

my_list = [100, 50, 65, 82, 23]
my_list.sort()
print(my_list)

To sort descending, use the keyword argument reverse = True.

In [ ]:
my_list = ["orange", "mango", "kiwi", "pineapple", "banana"]
my_list.sort(reverse = True)
print(my_list)

my_list = [100, 50, 65, 82, 23]
my_list.sort(reverse = True)
print(my_list)

You can also customize your own sort function by using the keyword argument key = function.

In [ ]:
def myfunc(n):
  return abs(n - 50)

my_list = [100, 50, 65, 82, 23]
my_list.sort(key = myfunc)
print(my_list)

By default the sort() method is case-sensitive, resulting in all capital letters being sorted before lower case letters.

In [ ]:
my_list = ["banana", "Orange", "Kiwi", "cherry"]
my_list.sort()
print(my_list)

To perform a case-insensitive sort, use str.lower as a key function.

In [ ]:
my_list = ["banana", "Orange", "Kiwi", "cherry"]
my_list.sort(key = str.lower)
print(my_list)

To reverse the order of a list, regardless of the alphabet, use the reverse() method.

In [ ]:
my_list = ["banana", "Orange", "Kiwi", "cherry"]
my_list.reverse()
print(my_list)

Copy Lists¶

You cannot simply copy a list by typing list2 = list1, because list2 will only be a reference to list1, and changes made in list1 will automatically also be made in list2.

There are ways to make a copy, one way is to use the built-in List method copy().

In [ ]:
my_list = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
my_list_copy = my_list.copy()
print(my_list_copy)

Another way to make a copy is to use the built-in method list().

In [ ]:
my_list = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
my_list_copy = list(my_list)
print(my_list_copy)

Join Lists¶

There are several ways to join, or concatenate, two or more lists in Python.

One of the easiest ways are by using the + operator.

In [ ]:
list1 = ["a", "b" , "c"]
list2 = [1, 2, 3]

list3 = list1 + list2
print(list3)

Another way to join two lists is by appending all the items from list2 into list1, one by one.

In [ ]:
list1 = ["a", "b" , "c"]
list2 = [1, 2, 3]

for x in list2:
  list1.append(x)

print(list1)

Or you can use the extend() method, which purpose is to add elements from another iterable (like a list, tuple, set, or dictionary) to the current list.

In [ ]:
list1 = ["a", "b" , "c"]
list2 = [1, 2, 3]

list1.extend(list2)
print(list1)

List Methods¶

Python has a set of built-in methods that you can use on lists.

Method Description
append() Adds an element at the end of the list
clear() Removes all the elements from the list
copy() Returns a copy of the list
count() Returns the number of elements with the specified value
extend() Add the elements of a list (or any iterable), to the end of the current list
index() Returns the index of the first element with the specified value
insert() Adds an element at the specified position
pop() Removes the element at the specified position
remove() Removes the first item with the specified value
reverse() Reverses the order of the list
sort() Sorts the list

List Exercises¶

Exercise 1: Print the second item in the fruits list.

In [ ]:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
In [ ]:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
In [ ]:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
In [ ]:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
In [ ]:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
In [ ]:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange", "kiwi", "melon", "mango"]
In [ ]:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
In [ ]:
my_tuple = ("apple", "banana", "cherry")
print(my_tuple)

Access Tuples¶

You can access tuple items by referring to the index number, inside square brackets.

In [ ]:
my_tuple = ("apple", "banana", "cherry")
print(my_tuple[1])

Negative indexing is also supported.

In [ ]:
my_tuple = ("apple", "banana", "cherry")
print(my_tuple[-1])

You can access a range of items by specifying a start and end index.

In [ ]:
my_tuple = ("apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange", "kiwi", "melon", "mango")
print(my_tuple[2:5]) # Items from index 2 (included) to 5 (not included)
print(my_tuple[:4])  # Items from the beginning to index 4 (not included)
print(my_tuple[2:])  # Items from index 2 (included) to the end
print(my_tuple[-4:-1]) # Items from index -4 (included) to -1 (not included)

Update Tuples¶

Tuples are immutable, meaning you cannot change, add, or remove items after the tuple is created. However, there are workarounds.

One way is to convert the tuple into a list, change the list, and convert the list back into a tuple.

In [ ]:
my_tuple = ("apple", "banana", "cherry")
my_list = list(my_tuple)
my_list[1] = "blackcurrant"
my_tuple = tuple(my_list)
print(my_tuple)

To add items, convert into a list, append the item(s), and convert back into a tuple.

In [ ]:
my_tuple = ("apple", "banana", "cherry")
my_list = list(my_tuple)
my_list.append("orange")
my_tuple = tuple(my_list)
print(my_tuple)

To remove items, convert into a list, remove the item(s), and convert back into a tuple.

In [ ]:
my_tuple = ("apple", "banana", "cherry")
my_list = list(my_tuple)
my_list.remove("banana")
my_tuple = tuple(my_list)
print(my_tuple)

You can delete the tuple completely using the del keyword.

In [ ]:
my_tuple = ("apple", "banana", "cherry")
# del my_tuple # This would delete the tuple
# print(my_tuple) # This would cause an error

Unpack Tuples¶

When we create a tuple, we normally assign values to it. This is called "packing" a tuple.

In [ ]:
fruits = ("apple", "banana", "cherry")

But, we are also allowed to extract the values back into variables. This is called "unpacking".

In [ ]:
fruits = ("apple", "banana", "cherry")
(green, yellow, red) = fruits
print(green)
print(yellow)
print(red)

If the number of variables is less than the number of values, you can add an * to the variable name and the values will be assigned to the variable as a list.

In [ ]:
fruits = ("apple", "banana", "cherry", "strawberry", "raspberry")
(green, yellow, *red) = fruits
print(green)
print(yellow)
print(red)

If the asterisk is added to another variable name than the last, the values will be assigned to the variable as a list, and the rest of the values will be assigned to the variables as usual.

In [ ]:
fruits = ("apple", "mango", "pineapple", "papaya", "cherry")
(green, *tropic, red) = fruits
print(green)
print(tropic)
print(red)

Loop Tuples¶

You can loop through the tuple items by using a for loop.

In [ ]:
my_tuple = ("apple", "banana", "cherry")
for x in my_tuple:
  print(x)

You can also loop through the tuple items by referring to their index number.

In [ ]:
my_tuple = ("apple", "banana", "cherry")
for i in range(len(my_tuple)):
  print(my_tuple[i])

You can use a while loop to loop through the tuple items.

In [ ]:
my_tuple = ("apple", "banana", "cherry")
i = 0
while i < len(my_tuple):
  print(my_tuple[i])
  i = i + 1

Join Tuples¶

To join two or more tuples you can use the + operator.

In [ ]:
tuple1 = ("a", "b" , "c")
tuple2 = (1, 2, 3)

tuple3 = tuple1 + tuple2
print(tuple3)

You can multiply the content of a tuple by using the * operator.

In [ ]:
fruits = ("apple", "banana", "cherry")
mytuple = fruits * 2
print(mytuple)

Tuple Methods¶

Python has a set of built-in methods that you can use on tuples.

Method Description
count() Returns the number of times a specified value occurs in a tuple
index() Searches the tuple for a specified value and returns the position of where it was found

Tuple Exercises¶

Exercise 1: Print the first item in the fruits tuple.

In [ ]:
fruits = ("apple", "banana", "cherry")
In [ ]:
fruits = ("apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange", "kiwi", "melon", "mango")
In [ ]:
tuple1 = ("a", "b", "c")
tuple2 = (1, 2, 3)

Python Sets¶

Sets are unordered, mutable collections of unique items. They are defined using curly braces {} or the set() constructor. Duplicate values are not allowed in sets.

In [ ]:
my_set = {"apple", "banana", "cherry"}
print(my_set)

# Duplicate values will be ignored
my_set = {"apple", "banana", "cherry", "apple"}
print(my_set)

Access Set Items¶

You cannot access items in a set by referring to an index or a key, as sets are unordered. However, you can loop through the set items using a for loop, or ask if a specified value is present in a set, by using the in keyword.

In [ ]:
my_set = {"apple", "banana", "cherry"}

for x in my_set:
  print(x)

print("banana" in my_set)

Add Set Items¶

To add one item to a set, use the add() method.

In [ ]:
my_set = {"apple", "banana", "cherry"}
my_set.add("orange")
print(my_set)

To add multiple items to a set, use the update() method. The object in the update() method can be any iterable (like List, Tuple, Dictionary etc.).

In [ ]:
my_set = {"apple", "banana", "cherry"}
my_set.update(["mango", "grape"])
print(my_set)

Remove Set Items¶

To remove an item in a set, use the remove() method or the discard() method.

In [ ]:
my_set = {"apple", "banana", "cherry"}
my_set.remove("banana")
print(my_set)

If the item to remove does not exist, remove() will raise an error. discard() will NOT raise an error.

In [ ]:
my_set = {"apple", "banana", "cherry"}
my_set.discard("mango") # Does not raise an error
print(my_set)

You can also use the pop() method to remove an item, but since sets are unordered, you will not know which item gets removed.

In [ ]:
my_set = {"apple", "banana", "cherry"}
x = my_set.pop()
print(x)
print(my_set)

The clear() method empties the set.

In [ ]:
my_set = {"apple", "banana", "cherry"}
my_set.clear()
print(my_set)

The del keyword will delete the set completely.

In [ ]:
my_set = {"apple", "banana", "cherry"}
# del my_set # This would delete the set
# print(my_set) # This would cause an error

Loop Sets¶

You can loop through the set items by using a for loop.

In [ ]:
my_set = {"apple", "banana", "cherry"}
for x in my_set:
  print(x)

Join Sets¶

There are several ways to join two or more sets in Python.

The union() method returns a new set containing all items from both sets.

In [ ]:
set1 = {"a", "b" , "c"}
set2 = {1, 2, 3}

set3 = set1.union(set2)
print(set3)

The update() method inserts all the items from one set into another.

In [ ]:
set1 = {"a", "b" , "c"}
set2 = {1, 2, 3}

set1.update(set2)
print(set1)

Both union() and update() will exclude any duplicate items.

Set Methods¶

Python has a set of built-in methods that you can use on sets.

Method Description
add() Adds an element to the set
clear() Removes all the elements from the set
copy() Returns a copy of the set
difference() Returns a set containing the difference between two or more sets
difference_update() Removes the items in this set that are also included in another specified set
discard() Remove the specified item
intersection() Returns a set, that is the intersection of two other sets
intersection_update() Removes the items in this set that are not present in other specified set(s)
isdisjoint() Returns whether two sets have a intersection or not
issubset() Returns whether another set contains this set, or it contains all values in this set
issuperset() Returns whether this set contains another set, or it contains all values in the specified set
pop() Removes an element from the set
remove() Removes the specified element
symmetric_difference() Returns a set with the symmetric differences of two sets
symmetric_difference_update() Inserts the symmetric differences from another set into the current set
union() Return a set containing all items from both sets, duplicates are excluded
update() Update the current set, by adding items from another set (or any other iterable)

Set Exercises¶

Exercise 1: Add "orange" to the fruits set.

In [ ]:
fruits = {"apple", "banana", "cherry"}

Exercise 2: Remove "banana" from the fruits set.

In [ ]:
fruits = {"apple", "banana", "cherry"}

Python Dictionaries¶

Dictionaries are unordered (in Python versions before 3.7, ordered in 3.7+), mutable collections of key-value pairs. They are defined using curly braces {} with keys and values separated by colons :. Dictionary items are presented in key:value pairs, and can be referred to by using the key name.

In [ ]:
my_dict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}
print(my_dict)

Access Items¶

You can access the items of a dictionary by referring to its key name, inside square brackets.

In [ ]:
my_dict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}
print(my_dict["model"])

There is also a method called get() that will give you the same result.

In [ ]:
my_dict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}
print(my_dict.get("model"))

You can get a list of the keys using the keys() method.

In [ ]:
my_dict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}
x = my_dict.keys()
print(x) # Before the change

my_dict["color"] = "white"
print(x) # After the change

You can get a list of the values using the values() method.

In [ ]:
my_dict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}
x = my_dict.values()
print(x) # Before the change

my_dict["year"] = 2020
print(x) # After the change

You can get a list of the key:value pairs using the items() method.

In [ ]:
my_dict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}
x = my_dict.items()
print(x) # Before the change

my_dict["year"] = 2020
print(x) # After the change

Change Items¶

You can change the value of a specific item by referring to its key name.

In [ ]:
my_dict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}
my_dict["year"] = 2020
print(my_dict)

Add Items¶

Adding an item to the dictionary is done by using a new index key and assigning a value to it.

In [ ]:
my_dict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}
my_dict["color"] = "red"
print(my_dict)

Remove Items¶

There are several methods to remove items from a dictionary.

The pop() method removes the item with the specified key name.

In [ ]:
my_dict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}
my_dict.pop("model")
print(my_dict)

The popitem() method removes the last inserted item (in versions before 3.7, a random item is removed instead).

In [ ]:
my_dict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}
my_dict.popitem()
print(my_dict)

The del keyword removes the item with the specified key name.

In [ ]:
my_dict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}
del my_dict["year"]
print(my_dict)

The del keyword can also delete the dictionary completely.

In [ ]:
my_dict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}
# del my_dict # This would delete the dictionary
# print(my_dict) # This would cause an error

The clear() method empties the dictionary.

In [ ]:
my_dict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}
my_dict.clear()
print(my_dict)

Loop Dictionaries¶

You can loop through a dictionary by using a for loop.

When looping through a dictionary, the return values are the keys of the dictionary, but there are methods to return the values as well.

In [ ]:
my_dict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}

for x in my_dict:
  print(x) # Prints keys

Print all values in the dictionary, one by one:

In [ ]:
my_dict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}

for x in my_dict:
  print(my_dict[x]) # Prints values

You can also use the values() method to return values of a dictionary.

In [ ]:
my_dict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}

for x in my_dict.values():
  print(x)

You can use the keys() method to return the keys of a dictionary.

In [ ]:
my_dict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}

for x in my_dict.keys():
  print(x)

Loop through both keys and values, by using the items() method.

In [ ]:
my_dict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}

for x, y in my_dict.items():
  print(x, y)

Copy Dictionaries¶

You cannot simply copy a dictionary by typing dict2 = dict1, because dict2 will only be a reference to dict1, and changes made in dict1 will automatically also be made in dict2.

There are ways to make a copy, one way is to use the built-in Dictionary method copy().

In [ ]:
my_dict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}
my_dict_copy = my_dict.copy()
print(my_dict_copy)

Another way to make a copy is to use the built-in method dict().

In [ ]:
my_dict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}
my_dict_copy = dict(my_dict)
print(my_dict_copy)

Nested Dictionaries¶

A dictionary can contain dictionaries, this is called nested dictionaries.

In [ ]:
my_family = {
  "child1" : {
    "name" : "Emil",
    "year" : 2004
  },
  "child2" : {
    "name" : "Tobias",
    "year" : 2007
  },
  "child3" : {
    "name" : "Linus",
    "year" : 2011
  }
}
print(my_family)

Or, if you want to add three dictionaries into a new dictionary as items:

In [ ]:
child1 = {
  "name" : "Emil",
  "year" : 2004
}
child2 = {
  "name" : "Tobias",
  "year" : 2007
}
child3 = {
  "name" : "Linus",
  "year" : 2011
}

my_family = {
  "child1" : child1,
  "child2" : child2,
  "child3" : child3
}
print(my_family)

Access Items in Nested Dictionaries¶

To access items from a nested dictionary, you can use the name of the dictionaries starting with the outer dictionary.

In [ ]:
my_family = {
  "child1" : {
    "name" : "Emil",
    "year" : 2004
  },
  "child2" : {
    "name" : "Tobias",
    "year" : 2007
  },
  "child3" : {
    "name" : "Linus",
    "year" : 2011
  }
}
print(my_family["child2"]["name"])

Dictionary Methods¶

Python has a set of built-in methods that you can use on dictionaries.

Method Description
clear() Removes all the elements from the dictionary
copy() Returns a copy of the dictionary
fromkeys() Returns a dictionary with the specified keys and value
get() Returns the value of the specified key
items() Returns a list containing a tuple for each key value pair
keys() Returns a list containing the dictionary's keys
pop() Removes the element with the specified key
popitem() Removes the last inserted key-value pair
setdefault() Returns the value of the specified key. If the key does not exist: insert the key, with the specified value
update() Updates the dictionary with the specified key-value pairs
values() Returns a list of all the values in the dictionary

Dictionary Exercises¶

Exercise 1: Print the "model" value of the car dictionary.

In [ ]:
car = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}

Exercise 2: Change the "year" value from 1964 to 2020.

In [ ]:
car = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}

Exercise 3: Add the key/value pair "color": "red" to the car dictionary.

In [ ]:
car = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}

Exercise 4: Use the pop() method to remove "model" from the car dictionary.

In [ ]:
car = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}

Exercise 5: Use the clear() method to empty the car dictionary.

In [ ]:
car = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}

Chapter 3: Control Flow¶

Control flow refers to the order in which the statements in a program are executed. In Python, control flow is managed by conditional statements (if-else) and loops (while, for).

Python If...Else¶

The if statement is used to test a specific condition. If the condition is true, the code inside the if block is executed.

In [ ]:
a = 200
b = 33
if b > a:
  print("b is greater than a")

The elif keyword is Python's way of saying "if the previous conditions were not true, then try this condition".

In [ ]:
a = 33
b = 33
if b > a:
  print("b is greater than a")
elif a == b:
  print("a and b are equal")

The else keyword catches anything which isn't caught by the preceding conditions.

In [ ]:
a = 200
b = 33
if b > a:
  print("b is greater than a")
elif a == b:
  print("a and b are equal")
else:
  print("a is greater than b")

You can also have a short hand if and if...else.

In [ ]:
if a > b: print("a is greater than b")
In [ ]:
a = 2
b = 330
print("A") if a > b else print("B")

You can combine multiple conditions using logical operators (and, or, not).

In [ ]:
a = 200
b = 33
c = 500
if a > b and c > a:
  print("Both conditions are True")
In [ ]:
a = 200
b = 33
c = 500
if a > b or a > c:
  print("At least one of the conditions is True")
In [ ]:
a = 33
b = 200
if not b > a:
  print("b is NOT greater than a")

Python Match¶

A match statement takes an expression and compares its value to successive case patterns.

In [ ]:
def http_status(status):
    match status:
        case 200:
            return "OK"
        case 404:
            return "Not Found"
        case 500:
            return "Internal Server Error"
        case _:
            return "Unknown Status"

print(http_status(200))
print(http_status(404))
print(http_status(501))

Python While Loops¶

The while loop executes a block of code as long as a specified condition is true.

In [ ]:
i = 1
while i < 6:
  print(i)
  i += 1

With the break statement we can stop the loop even if the while condition is true.

In [ ]:
i = 1
while i < 6:
  print(i)
  if i == 3:
    break
  i += 1

With the continue statement we can stop the current iteration, and continue with the next.

In [ ]:
i = 0
while i < 6:
  i += 1
  if i == 3:
    continue
  print(i)

With the else statement we can run a block of code once when the condition no longer is true.

In [ ]:
i = 1
while i < 6:
  print(i)
  i += 1
else:
  print("i is no longer less than 6")

Python For Loops¶

A for loop is used for iterating over a sequence (that is either a list, a tuple, a dictionary, a set, or a string).

In [ ]:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
for x in fruits:
  print(x)

Looping Through a String:

In [ ]:
for x in "banana":
  print(x)

With the break statement, we can stop the loop before it has looped through all the items.

In [ ]:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
for x in fruits:
  print(x)
  if x == "banana":
    break

With the continue statement, we can stop the current iteration of the loop, and continue with the next.

In [ ]:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
for x in fruits:
  if x == "banana":
    continue
  print(x)

To loop through a set of code a specified number of times, we can use the range() function.

In [ ]:
for x in range(6):
  print(x)

The else keyword in a for loop specifies a block of code to be executed when the loop is finished.

In [ ]:
for x in range(6):
  print(x)
else:
  print("Finally finished!")

Nested loops: A nested loop is a loop inside a loop.

In [ ]:
adj = ["red", "big", "tasty"]
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]

for x in adj:
  for y in fruits:
    print(x, y)

Chapter 4: Functions and Modules¶

Functions are blocks of reusable code that perform a specific task. Modules are files containing Python code that can be imported and used in other programs.

Python Functions¶

A function is defined using the def keyword, followed by the function name and parentheses (). Parameters can be passed inside the parentheses.

In [ ]:
def my_function():
  print("Hello from a function")

my_function()

Arguments are specified after the function name, inside the parentheses. You can add as many arguments as you want, just separate them with a comma.

In [ ]:
def my_function(fname):
  print(fname + " Refsnes")

my_function("Emil")
my_function("Tobias")
my_function("Linus")

Arbitrary Arguments, *args: If you do not know how many arguments that will be passed into your function, add a * before the parameter name in the function definition.

In [ ]:
def my_function(*kids):
  print("The youngest child is " + kids[2])

my_function("Emil", "Tobias", "Linus")

Keyword Arguments, **kwargs: You can also send arguments with the key = value syntax.

In [ ]:
def my_function(child3, child2, child1):
  print("The youngest child is " + child3)

my_function(child1 = "Emil", child2 = "Tobias", child3 = "Linus")

Arbitrary Keyword Arguments, **kwargs: If you do not know how many keyword arguments that will be passed into your function, add two asterisk: ** before the parameter name in the function definition.

In [ ]:
def my_function(**kid):
  print("His last name is " + kid["lname"])

my_function(fname = "Tobias", lname = "Refsnes")

Default Parameter Value: If we call the function without argument, it uses the default value.

In [ ]:
def my_function(country = "Norway"):
  print("I am from " + country)

my_function("Sweden")
my_function("India")
my_function()
my_function("Brazil")

Passing a List as an Argument: You can send any data types of argument to a function (string, number, list, dictionary etc.), and it will be treated as the same data type inside the function.

In [ ]:
def my_function(food):
  for x in food:
    print(x)

fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]

my_function(fruits)

Return Values: To let a function return a value, use the return statement.

In [ ]:
def my_function(x):
  return 5 * x

print(my_function(3))
print(my_function(5))
print(my_function(9))

Python Lambda¶

A lambda function is a small anonymous function. A lambda function can take any number of arguments, but can only have one expression.

In [ ]:
x = lambda a : a + 10
print(x(5))

Lambda functions can take any number of arguments:

In [ ]:
x = lambda a, b : a * b
print(x(5, 6))
In [ ]:
x = lambda a, b, c : a + b + c
print(x(5, 6, 2))

Why Use Lambda Functions? The power of lambda is better shown when you use them as an anonymous function inside another function.

In [ ]:
def myfunc(n):
  return lambda a : a * n

mydoubler = myfunc(2)
mytripler = myfunc(3)

print(mydoubler(11))
print(mytripler(11))

Python Arrays¶

Python does not have built-in support for Arrays, but Python Lists can be used as arrays.

In [ ]:
# Create an array
cars = ["Ford", "Volvo", "BMW"]

# Access the elements of an array
x = cars[0]
print(x)

# Modify the value of the first array item
cars[0] = "Toyota"
print(cars)

# The length of an array
x = len(cars)
print(x)

# Looping Array Elements
for x in cars:
  print(x)

# Adding Array Elements
cars.append("Honda")
print(cars)

# Removing Array Elements
cars.pop(1)
print(cars)

cars.remove("Ford")
print(cars)

Python OOP¶

Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) is a programming paradigm based on the concept of "objects", which can contain data and code: data in the form of fields (often known as attributes or properties), and code, in the form of procedures (often known as methods).

Python Classes and Objects¶

A Class is like an object constructor, or a "blueprint" for creating objects. To create a class, use the keyword class.

In [ ]:
class MyClass:
  x = 5

print(MyClass)

Now we can use the class named MyClass to create objects:

In [ ]:
class MyClass:
  x = 5

p1 = MyClass()
print(p1.x)

The __init__() Function: The examples above are classes and objects in their simplest form, and are not really useful in real life applications. To understand the meaning of classes we have to understand the built-in __init__() function.

The __init__() function is always executed when the class is being initiated. It is used to assign values to object properties, or other operations that are necessary to do when the object is being created.

In [ ]:
class Person:
  def __init__(self, name, age):
    self.name = name
    self.age = age

p1 = Person("John", 36)

print(p1.name)
print(p1.age)

Object Methods: Objects can also contain methods. Methods in objects are functions that belong to the object.

In [ ]:
class Person:
  def __init__(self, name, age):
    self.name = name
    self.age = age

  def myfunc(self):
    print("Hello my name is " + self.name)

p1 = Person("John", 36)
p1.myfunc()

The self parameter is a reference to the current instance of the class, and is used to access variables that belongs to the class. It does not have to be named self, you can call it whatever you like, but it has to be the first parameter of any function in the class.

In [ ]:
class Person:
  def __init__(mysillyobject, name, age):
    mysillyobject.name = name
    mysillyobject.age = age

  def myfunc(abc):
    print("Hello my name is " + abc.name)

p1 = Person("John", 36)
p1.myfunc()

Modify Object Properties: You can modify properties on objects as such:

In [ ]:
class Person:
  def __init__(self, name, age):
    self.name = name
    self.age = age

  def myfunc(self):
    print("Hello my name is " + self.name)

p1 = Person("John", 36)

p1.age = 40

print(p1.age)

Delete Object Properties: You can delete properties on objects by using the del keyword:

In [ ]:
class Person:
  def __init__(self, name, age):
    self.name = name
    self.age = age

  def myfunc(self):
    print("Hello my name is " + self.name)

p1 = Person("John", 36)

del p1.age

# print(p1.age) # This would cause an error

Delete Objects: You can delete objects by using the del keyword:

In [ ]:
class Person:
  def __init__(self, name, age):
    self.name = name
    self.age = age

  def myfunc(self):
    print("Hello my name is " + self.name)

p1 = Person("John", 36)

# del p1 # This would delete the object
# print(p1) # This would cause an error

The pass Statement: class definitions cannot be empty, but if you for some reason have a class definition with no content, put in the pass statement to avoid getting an error.

In [ ]:
class MyClass:
  pass

Python Inheritance¶

Inheritance allows us to define a class that inherits all the methods and properties from another class.

Parent class is the class being inherited from, also called base class. Child class is the class that inherits from another class, also called derived class.

To create a class that inherits the functionality from another class, send the parent class as a parameter when creating the child class.

In [ ]:
class Person:
  def __init__(self, fname, lname):
    self.firstname = fname
    self.lastname = lname

  def printname(self):
    print(self.firstname, self.lastname)

x = Person("John", "Doe")
x.printname()
In [ ]:
class Student(Person):
  pass

x = Student("Mike", "Olsen")
x.printname()

Add the __init__() Function: So far, we have created a child class that inherits the properties and methods from its parent. We want to add the __init__() function to the child class (like we do in normal classes).

When you add the __init__() function, the child class will no longer inherit the parent's __init__() function. To keep the inheritance of the parent's __init__() function, add a call to the parent's __init__() function.

In [ ]:
class Person:
  def __init__(self, fname, lname):
    self.firstname = fname
    self.lastname = lname

  def printname(self):
    print(self.firstname, self.lastname)

class Student(Person):
  def __init__(self, fname, lname):
    Person.__init__(self, fname, lname)

x = Student("Mike", "Olsen")
x.printname()

Use the super() Function: Python also has a super() function that will make the child class inherit all the methods and properties from its parent.

In [ ]:
class Person:
  def __init__(self, fname, lname):
    self.firstname = fname
    self.lastname = lname

  def printname(self):
    print(self.firstname, self.lastname)

class Student(Person):
  def __init__(self, fname, lname):
    super().__init__(fname, lname)

x = Student("Mike", "Olsen")
x.printname()

Add Properties: Add properties to the child class:

In [ ]:
class Person:
  def __init__(self, fname, lname):
    self.firstname = fname
    self.lastname = lname

  def printname(self):
    print(self.firstname, self.lastname)

class Student(Person):
  def __init__(self, fname, lname, year):
    super().__init__(fname, lname)
    self.graduationyear = year

x = Student("Mike", "Olsen", 2019)
print(x.graduationyear)

Add Methods: Add methods to the child class:

In [ ]:
class Person:
  def __init__(self, fname, lname):
    self.firstname = fname
    self.lastname = lname

  def printname(self):
    print(self.firstname, self.lastname)

class Student(Person):
  def __init__(self, fname, lname, year):
    super().__init__(fname, lname)
    self.graduationyear = year

  def welcome(self):
    print("Welcome", self.firstname, self.lastname, "to the class of", self.graduationyear)

x = Student("Mike", "Olsen", 2019)
x.welcome()

If you add a method in the child class with the same name as a function in the parent class, the inheritance of the parent method will be overridden.

Python Iterators¶

An iterator is an object that contains a countable number of values. An iterator is an object that can be iterated upon, meaning that you can traverse through all the values.

In Python, an iterator is an object which implements the iterator protocol, which consist of the methods __iter__() and __next__().

In [ ]:
my_tuple = ("apple", "banana", "cherry")
my_iterator = iter(my_tuple)

print(next(my_iterator))
print(next(my_iterator))
print(next(my_iterator))

Strings are also iterable objects, they contain a sequence of characters:

In [ ]:
my_string = "banana"
my_iterator = iter(my_string)

print(next(my_iterator))
print(next(my_iterator))
print(next(my_iterator))
print(next(my_iterator))
print(next(my_iterator))
print(next(my_iterator))

Create an Iterator: To create an object/class as an iterator you have to implement the methods __iter__() and __next__() to your object.

The __iter__() method returns the iterator object itself. If you want to do some initializing, this is the place to do it.

The __next__() method also returns the next item in the sequence.

In [ ]:
class MyNumbers:
  def __iter__(self):
    self.a = 1
    return self

  def __next__(self):
    x = self.a
    self.a += 1
    return x

myclass = MyNumbers()
myiter = iter(myclass)

print(next(myiter))
print(next(myiter))
print(next(myiter))
print(next(myiter))
print(next(myiter))

StopIteration: The example above would continue forever if you had enough next() statements! To avoid the iteration to go on forever, we can use the StopIteration statement.

In the __next__() method, we can add a terminating condition to raise an error if the iteration is done a specified number of times.

In [ ]:
class MyNumbers:
  def __iter__(self):
    self.a = 1
    return self

  def __next__(self):
    if self.a <= 20:
      x = self.a
      self.a += 1
      return x
    else:
      raise StopIteration

myclass = MyNumbers()
myiter = iter(myclass)

for x in myiter:
  print(x)

Python Polymorphism¶

Polymorphism means "many forms", and in programming, it refers to methods/functions/operators with the same name that can be executed on many objects or types.

Polymorphism in Class Methods:

In [ ]:
class Car:
  def __init__(self, brand, model):
    self.brand = brand
    self.model = model

  def move(self):
    print("Drive!")

class Boat:
  def __init__(self, brand, model):
    self.brand = brand
    self.model = model

  def move(self):
    print("Sail!")

class Plane:
  def __init__(self, brand, model):
    self.brand = brand
    self.model = model

  def move(self):
    print("Fly!")

car1 = Car("Ford", "Mustang")       # Create a Car object
boat1 = Boat("Ibiza", "Touring 20") # Create a Boat object
plane1 = Plane("Boeing", "747")     # Create a Plane object

for x in (car1, boat1, plane1):
  x.move()

Polymorphism in Functions:

In [ ]:
def my_function(a, b):
  return a + b

print(my_function(2, 3))
print(my_function("Hello", "World"))
print(my_function([1, 2], [3, 4]))

Python Scope¶

A variable is only available from inside the region it is created. This is called scope.

Local Scope: A variable created inside a function belongs to the local scope of that function, and can only be used inside that function.

In [ ]:
def myfunc():
  x = 300
  print(x)

myfunc()

A variable created inside a function is available for use inside any other function inside the same function:

In [ ]:
def myfunc():
  x = 300
  def myinnerfunc():
    print(x)
  myinnerfunc()

myfunc()

Global Scope: A variable created in the main body of the Python code is a global variable and belongs to the global scope. Global variables are available from within any scope, global and local.

In [ ]:
x = 300

def myfunc():
  print(x)

myfunc()

print(x)

Naming Variables: If you operate with the same variable name in both global and local scope, the local variable will make the global variable with the same name be ignored.

In [ ]:
x = 300

def myfunc():
  x = 200
  print(x)

myfunc()

print(x)

Global Keyword: If you want to create a global variable inside a function, you can use the global keyword.

In [ ]:
def myfunc():
  global x
  x = 300

myfunc()

print(x)

Also, use the global keyword if you want to make a change to a global variable inside a function.

In [ ]:
x = 300

def myfunc():
  global x
  x = 200

myfunc()

print(x)

Python Modules¶

A module is a file containing Python code. It can define functions, classes, and variables, and can contain runnable code.

To create a module, save the code you want in a file with the file extension .py.

Example: Save this code in a file named mymodule.py

In [ ]:
def greeting(name):
  print("Hello, " + name)

To use the module, use the import statement.

In [ ]:
import mymodule

mymodule.greeting("Jonathan")

You can name the module file whatever you like, but it must have the file extension .py.

You can also import from a module using the from keyword.

In [ ]:
from mymodule import greeting

greeting("Jonathan")

Python Dates¶

Python has a built-in module called datetime to work with dates and times.

In [ ]:
import datetime

x = datetime.datetime.now()
print(x)

The date contains year, month, day, hour, minute, second, and microsecond.

The datetime module has many methods to return information about the date object.

In [ ]:
import datetime

x = datetime.datetime.now()

print(x.year)
print(x.strftime("%A"))

Creating Date Objects: To create a date object, we can use the datetime() class (constructor) of the datetime module. The datetime() class requires three parameters to create a date: year, month, day.

In [ ]:
import datetime

x = datetime.datetime(2020, 5, 17)

print(x)

The strftime() Method: The datetime object has a method for formatting date objects into readable strings. The method is called strftime(), and takes one parameter, format, to specify the format of the returned string.

In [ ]:
import datetime

x = datetime.datetime(2018, 6, 1)

print(x.strftime("%B"))

Here are some format codes you can use:

Directive Description Example
%a Weekday as locale's abbreviated name. Sun, Mon...
%A Weekday as locale's full name. Sunday, Monday...
%w Weekday as a decimal number, where 0 is Sunday and 6 is Saturday. 0, 1, ... , 6
%d Day of the month as a zero-padded decimal number. 01, 02, ..., 31
%b Month as locale's abbreviated name. Jan, Feb...
%B Month as locale's full name. January, February...
%m Month as a zero-padded decimal number. 01, 02, ..., 12
%y Year without century as a zero-padded decimal number. 00, 01, ..., 99
%Y Year with century as a decimal number. 2014, 2015...
%H Hour (24-hour clock) as a zero-padded decimal number. 00, 01, ..., 23
%I Hour (12-hour clock) as a zero-padded decimal number. 01, 02, ..., 12
%p Locale's equivalent of either AM or PM. AM, PM
%M Minute as a zero-padded decimal number. 00, 01, ..., 59
%S Second as a zero-padded decimal number. 00, 01, ..., 59
%f Microsecond as a decimal number, zero-padded on the left. 000000, ..., 999999
%Z Time zone name if time zone is known. CST, EST, UTC...
%z UTC offset in the form +HHMM or -HHMM (empty string if the object is naive). +0000, -0400...
%j Day of the year as a zero-padded decimal number. 001, 002, ..., 366
%U Week number of the year (Sunday as the first day of the week). All days in a new year preceding the first Sunday are considered to be in week 0. 00, 01, ..., 53
%W Week number of the year (Monday as the first day of the week). All days in a new year preceding the first Monday are considered to be in week 0. 00, 01, ..., 53
%c Locale's appropriate date and time representation. Tue Aug 16 21:30:00 2016
%x Locale's appropriate date representation. 08/16/16
%X Locale's appropriate time representation. 21:30:00
%% A literal '%' character. %

Python Math¶

Python has a built-in module called math that provides access to mathematical functions.

In [ ]:
import math

# Returns the ceiling of x, the smallest integer greater than or equal to x
print(math.ceil(1.4))

# Returns the floor of x, the largest integer less than or equal to x
print(math.floor(1.4))

# Returns the value of x to the power of y
print(math.pow(2, 3))

# Returns the square root of x
print(math.sqrt(64))

# Returns the value of PI
print(math.pi)

Python JSON¶

JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) is a lightweight data interchange format. Python has a built-in package called json to work with JSON data.

In [ ]:
import json

# some JSON:
x = '{ "name":"John", "age":30, "city":"New York"}'

# parse x:
y = json.loads(x)

# the result is a Python dictionary:
print(y["age"])

Convert a Python object into a JSON string:

In [ ]:
import json

# a Python object (dict):
x = {
  "name": "John",
  "age": 30,
  "city": "New York"
}

# convert into JSON:
y = json.dumps(x)

# the result is a JSON string:
print(y)

You can convert Python objects of the following types into JSON strings:

  • dict
  • list
  • tuple
  • string
  • int
  • float
  • True
  • False
  • None

Example of converting other Python objects into JSON strings:

In [ ]:
import json

print(json.dumps({"name": "John", "age": 30}))
print(json.dumps(["apple", "bananas"]))
print(json.dumps(("apple", "bananas")))
print(json.dumps("hello"))
print(json.dumps(123))
print(json.dumps(45.78))
print(json.dumps(True))
print(json.dumps(False))
print(json.dumps(None))

Format the Result: The example above prints a JSON string, but it is not very easy to read, with no indentations and line breaks.

The json.dumps() method has parameters to make it easier to read the result.

Use the indent parameter to define the numbers of indents:

In [ ]:
import json

x = {
  "name": "John",
  "age": 30,
  "married": True,
  "divorced": False,
  "children": ("Ann","Billy"),
  "pets": None,
  "cars": [
    {"model": "BMW 230", "mpg": 27.5},
    {"model": "Ford Edge", "mpg": 24.1}
  ]
}

# use four indents to make it easier to read:
print(json.dumps(x, indent=4))

Use the separators parameter to change the default separator from (", ", ": ") to (",", ": ").

In [ ]:
import json

x = {
  "name": "John",
  "age": 30,
  "married": True,
  "divorced": False,
  "children": ("Ann","Billy"),
  "pets": None,
  "cars": [
    {"model": "BMW 230", "mpg": 27.5},
    {"model": "Ford Edge", "mpg": 24.1}
  ]
}

# use . and a space to separate objects, and a space and = to separate keys from values:
print(json.dumps(x, indent=4, separators=(". ", " = ")))

Order the Result: The json.dumps() method has parameters to order the keys in the result.

Use the sort_keys parameter to specify if the result should be sorted or not.

In [ ]:
import json

x = {
  "name": "John",
  "age": 30,
  "married": True,
  "divorced": False,
  "children": ("Ann","Billy"),
  "pets": None,
  "cars": [
    {"model": "BMW 230", "mpg": 27.5},
    {"model": "Ford Edge", "mpg": 24.1}
  ]
}

# sort the keys in alphabetical order:
print(json.dumps(x, indent=4, sort_keys=True))

Python RegEx¶

A RegEx, or Regular Expression, is a sequence of characters that forms a search pattern. RegEx can be used to check if a string contains the specified search pattern.

Python has a built-in package called re to work with Regular Expressions.

In [ ]:
import re

txt = "The rain in Spain"
x = re.search("^The.*Spain$", txt)

if x:
  print("YES! We have a match!")
else:
  print("No match")

The re module offers a set of functions that allows us to search a string for a match:

  • findall(): Returns a list containing all matches
  • search(): Searches the string for a match, and returns a Match object if there is a match
  • split(): Splits the string where there is a match and returns a list
  • sub(): Replaces the matches with the text of your choice

Metacharacters are characters with a special meaning:

| Metacharacter | Description | Example | | :------------ | :----------------------------------------------------------- | :---------- | | [] | A set of characters | "[a-m]" | | \ | Signals a special sequence (can also be used to escape special characters) | "\d" | | . | Any character (except newline character) | "he..o" | | ^ | Starts with | "^hello" | | $ | Ends with | "world$" | | * | Zero or more occurrences | "a*" | | + | One or more occurrences | "a+" | | ? | Zero or one occurrences | "a?" | | {} | Exactly the specified number of occurrences | "a{2}" | | | | Either or | "falls|stays" | | () | Capture and group | |

Special Sequences are sequences that have a special meaning:

Sequence Description Example
\A Returns a match if the specified characters are at the beginning of the string "\AThe"
\b Returns a match where the specified characters are at the beginning or at the end of a word (raw string) r"\bain\b"
\B Returns a match where the specified characters are present, but NOT at the beginning (or at the end) of a word (raw string) r"\Bain\B"
\d Returns a match where the string contains digits (0-9) "\d"
\D Returns a match where the string DOES NOT contain digits "\D"
\s Returns a match where the string contains a white space character "\s"
\S Returns a match where the string DOES NOT contain a white space character "\S"
\w Returns a match where the string contains any word characters (a-z, A-Z, 0-9, and _ ) "\w"
\W Returns a match where the string DOES NOT contain any word characters "\W"
\Z Returns a match if the specified characters are at the end of the string "Spain\Z"

Sets are a set of characters inside a pair of square brackets [] with a special meaning:

| Set | Description | | :------- | :---------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | [arn] | Returns a match where one of the specified characters (a, r, or n) are present | | [a-n] | Returns a match for any lowercase character, alphabetically between a and n | | [^arn] | Returns a match for any character EXCEPT a, r, and n | | [0123] | Returns a match where any of the specified digits (0, 1, 2, or 3) are present | | [0-9] | Returns a match for any digit between 0 and 9 | | [0-5][0-9] | Returns a match for any two-digit numbers from 00 and 59 | | [a-zA-Z] | Returns a match for any character from a to z or A to Z | | [+] | In sets, +, *, ., |, (), $,{} has no special meaning, so [+] means: return a match for a + character |

Python PIP¶

PIP is a package manager for Python packages, or modules if you like. PIP is the preferred installer.

In [ ]:
# Install a package named "camelcase":
# !pip install camelcase

Once the package is installed, you can import it and use it in your applications.

In [ ]:
# import camelcase

# c = camelcase.CamelCase()

# txt = "hello world"

# print(c.hump(txt))

Find Packages: Find more packages at https://pypi.org/.

Install PIP: If you do not have PIP installed, you can download and install it from this page: https://pypi.org/project/pip/

Use a Package:

In [ ]:
# import camelcase

# c = camelcase.CamelCase()

# print(c.hump("hello world"))

Remove a Package: Use the uninstall command to remove a package.

In [ ]:
# !pip uninstall camelcase

List Packages: Use the list command to list all the packages installed on your system.

In [ ]:
# !pip list

Python Try...Except¶

The try block lets you test a block of code for errors. The except block lets you handle the error. The finally block lets you execute code, regardless of the result of the try- and except blocks.

When an error occurs, like when we try to read a file that does not exist, or when we try to divide a number by zero, Python will stop and generate an error message. These errors are called exceptions.

The try block will generate an exception, because x is not defined:

In [ ]:
# try:
#   print(x)
# except:
#   print("An exception occurred")

Many Exceptions: You can define as many exception blocks as you want, e.g. one for a TypeError, and one for a NameError.

In [ ]:
# try:
#   print(x)
# except NameError:
#   print("Variable x is not defined")
# except TypeError:
#   print("Type error")
# except:
#   print("Something else went wrong")

Else: You can use the else keyword to define a block of code to be executed if no errors were raised.

In [ ]:
# try:
#   print("Hello")
# except:
#   print("Something went wrong")
# else:
#   print("Nothing went wrong")

Finally: The finally block, if specified, will be executed regardless of whether the try block raises an error or not.

In [ ]:
# try:
#   print(x)
# except:
#   print("Something went wrong")
# finally:
#   print("The 'try except' is finished")

This can be useful to close objects and clean up resources:

In [ ]:
# try:
#   f = open("demofile.txt")
#   f.write("Lorum Ipsum")
# except:
#   print("Something went wrong when writing to the file")
# finally:
#   f.close()

Raise an exception: As a Python developer you can choose to throw an exception if a condition occurs. To throw (or raise) an exception, use the raise keyword.

In [ ]:
# x = -1

# if x < 0:
#   raise Exception("Sorry, no numbers below zero")

You can define what kind of error to raise, and the text to print to the user.

In [ ]:
# x = "hello"

# if not type(x) is int:
#   raise TypeError("Only integers are allowed")

Python String Formatting¶

As we learned in the Strings section, you cannot combine strings and numbers directly. We can use f-strings or the format() method.

Using f-strings:

In [ ]:
age = 36
txt = f"My name is John, I am {age}"
print(txt)

Using the format() method:

In [ ]:
age = 36
txt = "My name is John, and I am {}"
print(txt.format(age))

You can add multiple values:

In [ ]:
quantity = 3
itemno = 567
price = 49.95
myorder = "I want {} pieces of item {} for {} dollars."
print(myorder.format(quantity, itemno, price))

You can use index numbers to ensure the arguments are placed in the correct placeholders:

In [ ]:
quantity = 3
itemno = 567
price = 49.95
myorder = "I want to pay {2} dollars for {0} pieces of item {1}."
print(myorder.format(quantity, itemno, price))

Named Indexes: You can also use named indexes by entering a name inside the curly brackets {}.

In [ ]:
myorder = "I have a {carname}, it is a {model}."
print(myorder.format(carname = "Ford", model = "Mustang"))

Python User Input¶

Python allows for user input. That means we are able to ask the user for input. The method is a bit different in Python 3.6 than Python 2.7.

Python 3.6 uses the input() method.

In [ ]:
# username = input("Enter username:")
# print("Username is: " + username)

Python 2.7 uses the raw_input() method.

In [ ]:
# Python 2.7 users should use raw_input()
# username = raw_input("Enter username:")
# print("Username is: " + username)

Python Virtual Environments¶

A virtual environment is a self-contained directory tree that contains a Python installation for a particular version of Python, plus a number of additional packages. This allows you to manage dependencies for different projects separately, avoiding conflicts.

Creating a Virtual Environment

Open your terminal or command prompt and navigate to your project directory. Run the following command:

In [ ]:
# python -m venv myenv

This command creates a directory named myenv (you can choose any name) within your project directory. This directory will contain the Python executable and a copy of the pip package installer.

Activating a Virtual Environment

Before you can install packages into your virtual environment, you need to activate it. The command to activate depends on your operating system and shell:

On Windows (Command Prompt):

In [ ]:
# myenv\Scripts\activate.bat

On Windows (PowerShell):

In [ ]:
# myenv\Scripts\Activate.ps1

On macOS and Linux:

In [ ]:
# source myenv/bin/activate

Once activated, your terminal prompt will usually show the name of the virtual environment (e.g., (myenv) your_username@your_computer:~/$).

Deactivating a Virtual Environment

To leave the virtual environment and return to your system's global Python environment, run the following command:

In [ ]:
# deactivate

Installing Packages in a Virtual Environment

With your virtual environment activated, you can use pip to install packages, and they will be installed within the virtual environment's directory, not globally on your system.

In [ ]:
# pip install package_name

Chapter 5: File Handling¶

File handling is an essential part of any web application. Python has functions for creating, reading, updating, and deleting files.

Python File Handling¶

The key function for working with files in Python is the open() function. The open() function takes two parameters: filename, and mode.

There are four different methods (modes) for opening a file:

  • "r" - Read - Default value. Opens a file for reading, error if the file does not exist
  • "a" - Append - Opens a file for appending, creates the file if it does not exist
  • "w" - Write - Opens a file for writing, creates the file if it does not exist
  • "x" - Create - Creates the specified file, returns an error if the file exists

In addition you can specify if the file should be handled as binary or text mode:

  • "t" - Text - Default value. Text mode
  • "b" - Binary - Binary mode (e.g. images)

Syntax: open("filename", "mode")

Python Read Files¶

To open a file for reading, use the "r" mode.

In [ ]:
# To open and read a file, the file must exist in the same directory as your Python script.
# Or, you can specify the full path to the file.

# Example: Assuming a file named "demofile.txt" exists with content:
# Hello! Welcome to demofile.txt
# This file is for testing purposes.
# Good Luck!

# f = open("demofile.txt", "r")
# print(f.read())

Read Only Parts of the File: By default the read() method returns the whole text, but you can specify how many characters you want to return.

In [ ]:
# f = open("demofile.txt", "r")
# print(f.read(5)) # Read only the first 5 characters

Read Lines: You can return one line by using the readline() method.

# f = open("demofile.txt", "r")

You can loop through the file line by line, using a for loop:

In [ ]:
# f = open("demofile.txt", "r")
# for x in f:
#   print(x)

Close Files: It is a good practice to always close the file when you are done with it.

In [ ]:
# f = open("demofile.txt", "r")
# print(f.readline())
# f.close()

# Note: You should always close your files, in some cases, due to buffering,
# changes made to a file may not show until you close the file.

Python Write/Create Files¶

To write to an existing file, you must add a parameter to the open() function:

  • "a" - Append - will append to the end of the file
  • "w" - Write - will overwrite any existing content

If you use the "w" mode, the file will be created if it does not exist.

In [ ]:

To create a new file in Python, use the open() method, with one of the following modes:

  • "x" - Create - will create a file, returns an error if the file exists
  • "a" - Append - will create a file if the specified file does not exist
  • "w" - Write - will create a file if the specified file does not exist

Chapter 6: Exception Handling¶

Exception handling is a mechanism to deal with errors that occur during the execution of a program.

Python Try Except¶

The try block lets you test a block of code for errors. The except block lets you handle the error.

In [ ]:
try:
  print(x)
except:
  print("An exception occurred")

You can define different exception blocks for different error types.

In [ ]:
try:
  print(x)
except NameError:
  print("Variable x is not defined")
except TypeError:
  print("Type error")
except:
  print("Something else went wrong")

Python Finally¶

The finally block, if specified, will be executed regardless of whether the try block raises an error or not.

In [ ]:
try:
  print("Hello")
except:
  print("Something went wrong")
finally:
  print("The 'try except' is finished")

This is useful for cleanup actions, like closing files.

In [ ]:
# try:
#   f = open("demofile.txt")
#   try:
#     f.write("Lorum Ipsum")
#   except:
#     print("Something went wrong when writing to the file")
#   finally:
#     f.close()
# except:
#   print("Something went wrong when opening the file")
