Problem 141: Longest Increasing Subsequence (N log N Solution)¶

Problem Statement:

Given an integer array nums, return the length of the longest strictly increasing subsequence. Your algorithm should be O(n log n) time complexity.

Input Format:

The first line contains an integer n, the size of the array. The second line contains n space-separated integers representing the array nums.

Constraints:

1 <= nums.length <= 2500 -10^4 <= nums[i] <= 10^4

Output Format:

Print the length of the longest strictly increasing subsequence.

Deep Explanation:

While the O(n^2) dynamic programming approach for LIS is intuitive, a more efficient O(n log n) solution exists using patience sorting. The core idea is to maintain a sorted list (let's call it tails) where tails[i] is the smallest tail of all increasing subsequences of length i+1.

When we iterate through the input array nums, for each number num:

  1. If num is greater than the last element in tails, it means we can extend the longest increasing subsequence found so far by adding num. We append num to tails. The length of tails increases, indicating a new longest increasing subsequence length.
  2. If num is not greater than the last element in tails, it means num can potentially be the new smallest tail of an existing increasing subsequence length. We find the smallest element in tails that is greater than or equal to num using binary search (bisect_left). We replace that element with num. This is because replacing a larger tail with a smaller num allows for potentially longer increasing subsequences in the future that can extend from this smaller tail. The length of tails does not change in this case.

The length of the tails list at the end of the iteration is the length of the longest increasing subsequence.

Time and Space Complexity:

  • Time Complexity: O(n log n). We iterate through the input array once (n elements). For each element, we perform a binary search on the tails list. The tails list has a maximum length of n. Binary search takes O(log n) time. Thus, the total time complexity is O(n log n).
  • Space Complexity: O(n). We use the tails list, which can store up to n elements in the worst case.

Solution Code:

In [ ]:
import bisect

def length_of_lis_nlogn(nums):
    """
    Calculates the length of the longest strictly increasing subsequence in O(n log n) time.

    Args:
        nums: A list of integers.

    Returns:
        The length of the longest increasing subsequence.
    """
    # tails[i] is the smallest tail of all increasing subsequences of length i+1
    tails = []

    for num in nums:
        # Use bisect_left to find the index where num can be inserted
        # to maintain sorted order and find the smallest element >= num
        idx = bisect.bisect_left(tails, num)

        if idx == len(tails):
            # If num is greater than all tails, extend the longest subsequence
            tails.append(num)
        else:
            # If num is not greater than all tails, replace the smallest tail
            # that is greater than or equal to num
            tails[idx] = num

    # The length of the tails list is the length of the LIS
    return len(tails)

# Read the size of the array
n = int(input())

# Read the array elements
nums = list(map(int, input().split()))

# Calculate and print the length of the LIS
print(length_of_lis_nlogn(nums))

Problem 142: Edit Distance¶

Problem Statement:

Given two strings word1 and word2, return the minimum number of operations required to convert word1 to word2. You have the following three operations permitted on a word: Insert a character, Delete a character, Replace a character.

Input Format:

The first line contains string word1. The second line contains string word2.

Constraints:

0 <= word1.length, word2.length <= 500 word1 and word2 consist of lowercase English letters.

Output Format:

Print the minimum number of operations (edit distance).

Deep Explanation:

This is a classic dynamic programming problem. We can use a 2D array, dp, where dp[i][j] represents the minimum number of operations required to convert the first i characters of word1 (word1[:i]) to the first j characters of word2 (word2[:j]).

  • Base Cases:

    • dp[0][0] = 0 (converting an empty string to an empty string requires 0 operations).
    • dp[i][0] = i (converting the first i characters of word1 to an empty string requires i deletions).
    • dp[0][j] = j (converting an empty string to the first j characters of word2 requires j insertions).

  • Recurrence Relation: For i > 0 and j > 0, to convert word1[:i] to word2[:j], we consider the last characters word1[i-1] and word2[j-1]:

    • If word1[i-1] == word2[j-1], the last characters match. No operation is needed for these characters. The minimum operations are the same as converting word1[:i-1] to word2[:j-1]: dp[i][j] = dp[i-1][j-1].
    • If word1[i-1] != word2[j-1], the last characters don't match. We have three possible operations:
      • Insert: Insert word2[j-1] into word1. The cost is 1 plus the minimum operations to convert word1[:i] to word2[:j-1]: 1 + dp[i][j-1].
      • Delete: Delete word1[i-1] from word1. The cost is 1 plus the minimum operations to convert word1[:i-1] to word2[:j]: 1 + dp[i-1][j].
      • Replace: Replace word1[i-1] with word2[j-1]. The cost is 1 plus the minimum operations to convert word1[:i-1] to word2[:j-1]: 1 + dp[i-1][j-1]. We take the minimum of these three costs: dp[i][j] = 1 + min(dp[i][j-1], dp[i-1][j], dp[i-1][j-1]).

The final answer is dp[len(word1)][len(word2)].

Time and Space Complexity:

  • Time Complexity: O(m * n), where m and n are the lengths of word1 and word2. We fill an m x n DP table.
  • Space Complexity: O(m * n) for the DP table. This can be optimized to O(min(m, n)) by noticing that we only need the previous row's values to calculate the current row.

Solution Code:

In [ ]:
def min_distance(word1, word2):
    """
    Calculates the minimum number of operations to convert word1 to word2 (Edit Distance).

    Args:
        word1: The first string.
        word2: The second string.

    Returns:
        The minimum number of operations.
    """
    m = len(word1)
    n = len(word2)

    # Create a 2D DP table
    dp = [[0] * (n + 1) for _ in range(m + 1)]

    # Base cases
    for i in range(m + 1):
        dp[i][0] = i  # i deletions to convert word1[:i] to ""
    for j in range(n + 1):
        dp[0][j] = j  # j insertions to convert "" to word2[:j]

    # Fill the DP table
    for i in range(1, m + 1):
        for j in range(1, n + 1):
            if word1[i - 1] == word2[j - 1]:
                # Last characters match, no operation needed for them
                dp[i][j] = dp[i - 1][j - 1]
            else:
                # Last characters don't match, consider insert, delete, or replace
                dp[i][j] = 1 + min(dp[i][j - 1],  # Insert
                                   dp[i - 1][j],  # Delete
                                   dp[i - 1][j - 1]) # Replace

    # The bottom-right cell contains the minimum edit distance
    return dp[m][n]

# Read the input strings
word1 = input()
word2 = input()

# Calculate and print the minimum edit distance
print(min_distance(word1, word2))

Problem 143: Maximum Profit in Job Scheduling¶

Problem Statement:

We have n jobs, where startTime[i] is the start time and endTime[i] is the finish time and profit[i] is the profit of the i-th job. You want to obtain maximum profit by scheduling the jobs such that no two jobs overlap. If you finish a job at time t, you can start another job at time t. Return the maximum profit you can obtain.

Input Format:

The first line contains an integer n, the number of jobs. The second line contains n space-separated integers representing startTime. The third line contains n space-separated integers representing endTime. The fourth line contains n space-separated integers representing profit.

Constraints:

1 <= n <= 5 * 10^4 1 <= startTime[i] < endTime[i] <= 10^9 1 <= profit[i] <= 10^4

Output Format:

Print the maximum profit.

Deep Explanation:

This problem is a variation of the weighted interval scheduling problem and can be solved using dynamic programming with binary search.

  1. Combine and Sort Jobs: Combine the start times, end times, and profits into a list of jobs, where each job is a tuple (endTime[i], startTime[i], profit[i]). Sort these jobs based on their finish times in ascending order. This sorting is crucial for the DP approach.
  2. Dynamic Programming: We can use a DP array, dp, where dp[i] represents the maximum profit obtainable from the first i + 1 jobs (after sorting by finish time).
  3. Recurrence Relation: For each job i (after sorting):
    • Option 1: Don't include job i. The maximum profit is the same as the maximum profit from the first i jobs: dp[i-1].
    • Option 2: Include job i. If we include job i, we cannot include any job that overlaps with it. Since the jobs are sorted by finish time, all jobs from i+1 onwards will finish after or at the same time as job i. We need to find the latest job j (where j < i) that finishes before job i starts (jobs[j][0] <= jobs[i][1]). We can efficiently find this using binary search on the sorted jobs based on their finish times. The maximum profit in this case is jobs[i][2] (profit of job i) plus the maximum profit obtainable from jobs up to job j (dp[j]).
    • dp[i] is the maximum of Option 1 and Option 2.

We need to handle the base cases and the binary search to find the non-overlapping job.

Time and Space Complexity:

  • Time Complexity: O(n log n). Sorting the jobs takes O(n log n). The DP iteration is O(n), and inside the loop, the binary search takes O(log n). Total time is O(n log n).
  • Space Complexity: O(n) for storing the jobs and the DP array.

Solution Code:

In [ ]:
import bisect

def job_scheduling(startTime, endTime, profit):
    """
    Calculates the maximum profit in job scheduling without overlapping jobs.

    Args:
        startTime: A list of start times.
        endTime: A list of end times.
        profit: A list of profits.

    Returns:
        The maximum profit.
    """
    n = len(startTime)
    # Combine jobs and sort by finish time
    jobs = sorted(zip(endTime, startTime, profit))

    # dp[i] will store the maximum profit from the first i+1 jobs
    dp = [0] * n
    # Base case: Maximum profit from the first job is its profit
    dp[0] = jobs[0][2]

    # Iterate through the jobs
    for i in range(1, n):
        current_profit = jobs[i][2]
        current_start_time = jobs[i][1]

        # Option 1: Don't include the current job
        max_profit_without_current = dp[i - 1]

        # Option 2: Include the current job
        # Find the latest non-overlapping job using binary search on finish times
        # We need to find the index of the latest job j such that jobs[j][0] <= current_start_time
        # bisect_right finds the insertion point such that all elements to the left are <= current_start_time
        # So, bisect_right(jobs, current_start_time, key=lambda x: x[0]) gives the index after the last job
        # with finish time <= current_start_time. We need the index itself, which is index - 1.
        # We search on the finish times of jobs up to index i-1
        idx = bisect.bisect_right(jobs[:i], current_start_time, key=lambda x: x[0])

        max_profit_with_current = current_profit
        if idx > 0:
             # Add the maximum profit from non-overlapping jobs before the current one
            max_profit_with_current += dp[idx - 1]


        # dp[i] is the maximum of the two options
        dp[i] = max(max_profit_without_current, max_profit_with_current)

    # The last element of dp contains the maximum profit
    return dp[n - 1]

# Read inputs
n = int(input())
startTime = list(map(int, input().split()))
endTime = list(map(int, input().split()))
profit = list(map(int, input().split()))

# Calculate and print the maximum profit
print(job_scheduling(startTime, endTime, profit))

Problem 144: Longest Valid Parentheses¶

Problem Statement:

Given a string containing just the characters '(' and ')', find the length of the longest valid (well-formed) parentheses substring.

Input Format:

A single string s containing only '(' and ')'.

Constraints:

1 <= s.length <= 3 * 10^4 s[i] is either '(' or ')'.

Output Format:

Print the length of the longest valid parentheses substring.

Deep Explanation:

This problem can be solved using dynamic programming or a stack.

Dynamic Programming: We can use a 1D array, dp, where dp[i] represents the length of the longest valid parentheses substring ending at index i.

  • Base case: dp[0] = 0.

  • Recurrence relation:

    • If s[i] is '(': dp[i] = 0 (a valid parentheses substring cannot end with an opening bracket alone).
    • If s[i] is ')':
      • If the previous character s[i-1] is '(': This forms a valid pair "()". The length is 2 plus the length of the valid substring ending at i-2 (if i >= 2). dp[i] = 2 + (dp[i-2] if i >= 2 else 0).
      • If the previous character s[i-1] is ')': This might be the end of a longer valid substring. We need to look for the matching opening bracket for s[i]. The matching opening bracket would be at index i - dp[i-1] - 1. If this index is valid (>= 0) and the character at this index is '(', then we have found a longer valid substring. The length is the length of the valid substring ending at i-1 (dp[i-1]) plus 2 (for the current pair) plus the length of the valid substring ending at the index before the matching opening bracket (dp[i - dp[i-1] - 2] if i - dp[i-1] >= 2). dp[i] = dp[i-1] + 2 + (dp[i - dp[i-1] - 2] if i - dp[i-1] >= 2 else 0).

The maximum value in the dp array is the length of the longest valid parentheses substring.

Stack Approach: We can use a stack to keep track of the indices of opening brackets. We initialize the stack with -1 to handle edge cases. We iterate through the string:

  • If s[i] is '(', push i onto the stack.
  • If s[i] is ')':
    • Pop the top element from the stack.
    • If the stack is empty, it means the current ')' does not have a matching '(', so push i onto the stack (this ')' acts as a new base for future valid substrings).
    • If the stack is not empty, the current valid substring length is i - stack.top(). Update the maximum length.

The maximum length found during the iteration is the answer.

We will provide the stack approach as it's generally more intuitive for this problem.

Solution Code:

In [ ]:
def longest_valid_parentheses(s):
    """
    Finds the length of the longest valid parentheses substring.

    Args:
        s: The input string of '(' and ')'.

    Returns:
        The length of the longest valid parentheses substring.
    """
    max_length = 0
    stack = [-1]  # Initialize stack with -1 to handle edge cases

    for i in range(len(s)):
        if s[i] == '(':
            stack.append(i)
        else: # s[i] == ')'
            stack.pop()
            if not stack:
                # If the stack becomes empty, the current ')' doesn't have a match.
                # Push the current index as a new base for future valid substrings.
                stack.append(i)
            else:
                # If the stack is not empty, a match is found.
                # The length of the current valid substring is the current index minus the index of the top of the stack.
                max_length = max(max_length, i - stack[-1])

    return max_length

# Read the input string
s = input()

# Calculate and print the length of the longest valid parentheses
print(longest_valid_parentheses(s))

Problem 145: Trapping Rain Water (Revisited)¶

Problem Statement:

Given n non-negative integers representing an elevation map where the width of each bar is 1, compute how much water it can trap after raining.

Input Format:

The first line contains an integer n, the number of bars. The second line contains n space-separated non-negative integers representing the elevation map height.

Constraints:

n == height.length 1 <= n <= 2 * 10^4 0 <= height[i] <= 10^5

Output Format:

Print the total amount of trapped rain water.

Deep Explanation:

This problem can be solved using various approaches, including two pointers, dynamic programming, or a stack. The two-pointer approach is often considered efficient and elegant.

Two-Pointer Approach: We initialize two pointers, left at the beginning of the array and right at the end. We also maintain left_max (the maximum height encountered from the left up to the current left pointer) and right_max (the maximum height encountered from the right up to the current right pointer). We iterate while left < right.

In each step, we compare left_max and right_max. The amount of water trapped at a position is determined by the height of the shorter boundary (the minimum of the maximum height to its left and the maximum height to its right) minus the height of the bar at that position.

  • If left_max < right_max: It means the height of the trapped water at left is limited by left_max. The water trapped at the current left position is left_max - height[left] (if positive). We add this to the total trapped water and move the left pointer (left += 1). We also update left_max if height[left] is greater than the current left_max.
  • If left_max >= right_max: It means the height of the trapped water at right is limited by right_max. The water trapped at the current right position is right_max - height[right] (if positive). We add this to the total trapped water and move the right pointer (right -= 1). We also update right_max if height[right] is greater than the current right_max.

We continue until left and right meet.

Time and Space Complexity:

  • Time Complexity: O(n). We iterate through the array once with two pointers.
  • Space Complexity: O(1). We only use a few variables for pointers and maximum heights.

Solution Code:

In [ ]:
def trap(height):
    """
    Calculates the amount of trapped rain water in an elevation map.

    Args:
        height: A list of non-negative integers representing bar heights.

    Returns:
        The total amount of trapped rain water.
    """
    if not height:
        return 0

    left = 0
    right = len(height) - 1
    left_max = 0
    right_max = 0
    trapped_water = 0

    while left < right:
        # Update left_max and right_max
        left_max = max(left_max, height[left])
        right_max = max(right_max, height[right])

        # If the left max is smaller, the water at the left pointer is limited by left_max
        if left_max < right_max:
            # Water trapped at the current left position (if positive)
            trapped_water += left_max - height[left]
            left += 1
        # If the right max is smaller or equal, the water at the right pointer is limited by right_max
        else:
            # Water trapped at the current right position (if positive)
            trapped_water += right_max - height[right]
            right -= 1

    return trapped_water

# Read the number of bars
n = int(input())

# Read the elevation map
height = list(map(int, input().split()))

# Calculate and print the trapped rain water
print(trap(height))

The Journey Continues: What to Do After Learning Python¶

Congratulations! Take a moment to truly appreciate what you've accomplished. You have successfully navigated the complexities of Python programming, from the foundational syntax to tackling challenging 3-star competitive programming problems. This was not a small feat, and your dedication and hard work have paid off. You haven't just learned a programming language; you've built a robust foundation in computational thinking, problem-solving, and algorithmic design that will serve you throughout your career.

Summary of Skills Gained¶

Through this comprehensive tutorial, you have acquired a wide range of valuable skills:

  • Core Python Proficiency: You are now comfortable with Python's syntax, data types, control flow, functions, and modules, adhering to best practices.
  • Essential Data Structures and Algorithms: You have a solid understanding and practical experience with fundamental data structures like lists, dictionaries, and sets, and essential algorithms such as sorting, searching, and basic graph traversals.
  • Competitive Programming Skills: You have developed the ability to analyze, design, and implement solutions for a variety of coding challenges, understanding time and space complexity.
  • Intermediate and Advanced Topics: You have been introduced to and gained experience with Object-Oriented Programming (OOP), file handling, and working with important Python libraries.

The Roadmap: What's Next?¶

Learning to code is a continuous journey of exploration and growth. Completing this tutorial is a powerful launchpad. Here are some crucial next steps to continue your development as a programmer:

Build Your Portfolio¶

One of the most effective ways to demonstrate your skills to potential employers or collaborators is through a portfolio of personal projects. This is where you apply what you've learned to solve problems that interest you.

  • Start Small: Begin with manageable projects. Ideas include:
    • A web scraper to gather data from websites.
    • A simple command-line utility for a task you perform often.
    • Implementing a classic game (like Tic-Tac-Toe or Hangman) in the console.
    • A script to automate a repetitive task on your computer.
    • A basic data analysis project using Pandas to visualize or find insights in a public dataset.
  • Use Version Control: Get comfortable with Git and host your projects on platforms like GitHub. This is a standard practice in the industry.

Deepen Your Knowledge¶

Expand your theoretical understanding of computer science concepts.

  • Algorithms and Data Structures: Explore more advanced data structures like trees (AVL, Red-Black), heaps, tries, and graphs (including their various representations). Learn about advanced algorithms such as graph traversal algorithms (Dijkstra's, A*), dynamic programming techniques, and algorithm design paradigms.
  • Software Design Patterns: Understand common design patterns to write more maintainable, scalable, and organized code.
  • Asynchronous Programming: Learn about handling concurrent tasks using concepts like threads, processes, and asynchronous programming with asyncio.

Specialize¶

Python is used in many domains. Choose an area that excites you and start specializing.

  • Web Development: Explore frameworks like Django (full-featured) or Flask (microframework) to build web applications. Learn about front-end technologies (HTML, CSS, JavaScript) to complement your back-end skills.
  • Data Science & Machine Learning: Dive deeper into libraries like NumPy, Pandas, Matplotlib, Seaborn, Scikit-learn, and frameworks like TensorFlow or PyTorch for machine learning and deep learning.
  • Automation & Scripting: Become an expert in writing scripts to automate tasks on different operating systems, working with APIs, and handling file system operations.
  • Other Fields: Explore areas like cybersecurity, game development (with libraries like Pygame), or scientific computing.

Contribute to Open Source¶

Engaging with the open-source community is invaluable.

  • Learn from Others: Read code written by experienced developers.
  • Gain Real-World Experience: Work on existing projects, fix bugs, or implement new features.
  • Build Your Network: Connect with other developers and become part of a community.
  • Start Small: Look for projects with beginner-friendly issues or documentation tasks.

Keep Practicing¶

Problem-solving is a skill that improves with practice.

  • Continue with Coding Challenges: Move on to higher-rated problems on platforms like CodeChef, LeetCode, and HackerRank. Try problems from different contests.
  • Timed Practice: Practice solving problems under timed conditions to simulate interview environments.
  • Teach Others: Explaining concepts to others is a great way to solidify your own understanding.

Your journey in the world of programming has just begun. Be curious, be persistent, and keep building. The skills you've developed provide a strong foundation for whatever path you choose to take next. Good luck, and happy coding!
